entry.title: How to avoid confirmed quantity to become zero after saving sales order?
entry.content:
The customer would like to know how can they avoid the system to always delete the confirmed quantity after saving the sales order.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to avoid confirmed quantity to become zero after...
entry.content:
In the current system design, when you apply a delivery block at the header level of a sales order, the system automatically transfers the requested delivery quantity to all schedule lines. As part of this process, any previously confirmed quantity is removed, which can result in the confirmed quantity becoming zero.

If your intention is to keep the confirmed quantity unchanged, you may consider applying the delivery block at the schedule line level instead. In this case, the system does not reset the confirmed quantity.

For a detailed explanation of this behavior, you can consult the F1 Help for the delivery block field at both header and schedule line levels, where the differences are documented.

entry.title: Re: How to avoid confirmed quantity to become zero after...
entry.content: Great answer!

In SAP Business ByDesign, 0% VAT lines in Customer Invoicing → Invoice Documents can't be hidden through configuration alone. entry.title: SAP Supply Chain Management Certification: Increase Your Expertise and Credibility
entry.content:
Running sustainable, resilient supply chains amid disruptions has become a driving force in many organizations. While supply chains have historically prioritized efficiency and cost reduction, digital technologies are delivering incredible gains to achieve even greater outcomes, while connecting processes and enabling faster insights.

In these times of rapid innovation, it’s becoming increasingly more critical to stay informed of the latest positioning guidance for SAP supply chain solutions. SAP has addressed this need by offering a non-technical certification option: Positioning SAP Business Suite via SAP Supply Chain Management Solutions. The non-technical certifications options are designed to be completed in a matter of few hours, thus making it a great option for individuals who are new to certification, looking to replace an expired certification, or simply interested in cultivating expertise with selling SAP supply chain solutions. 

Becoming certified in SAP supply chain management solutions will prepare you to gain the confidence and trust in your biggest stakeholder, the Chief Operating Officer (“COO”). The self-paced learning content will cover these key areas:

  • The end-to-end solution portfolio and how it addresses key priorities for the COO
  • How to position Supply Chain Management solutions in the context of SAP Business Suite
  • How AI is being used today in modern business settings as well as how it fits into the SAP’s Business AI strategy.
  • Selling SAP Supply Chain Management solutions to the COO through qualification, discovery, and packaging. 

Upon completing the digital learning, your certification attainment is achieved by:

  • Successful completion of a one-hour exam that will include thirty questions derived from the self-paced learning content
  • Submission of one of the following hands-on exercises:
    • Articulating the value of SAP supply chain solutions through an executive pitch
    • Demonstrating the value of SAP supply chain solutions by performing a demo.

Don’t Delay—take advantage of this opportunity to establish your credibility in SAP supply chain management and showcase your accomplishment. With around 5 hours of self-paced learning, this certification option is achievable for any busy professional and will provide tangible value in your field of expertise. Visit the SAP Learning Site to review the available certifications and select Positioning SAP Business Suite via SAP Supply Chain Management so you can start expertly positioning SAP’s supply chain management solutions to solve your customer’s key challenges and deliver real-world results.

Lauren Edwards

SAP Industries & Experience, Partner Solution Enablement - Supply Chain Management

entry.title: Re: Certification not received
entry.content:
Hello @ABHINAV1402 

Here’s What You Can Do Fast

Double-check your SAP Universal ID setup

Make sure it’s active and linked to two valid email addresses (primary & recovery). Official guidance says that without this, the badge won’t be issued by learninghub.sap.com.

Confirm your exam is logged in the SAP Learning portal

Go to My Learning → Certifications. If the exam isn’t listed, the issue is on SAP’s side, not Credly’s

Push again with SAP support, only this time, escalate

Log into the SAP Learning Help Center, choose Digital Badge as your service category, and include:

  • Your Case ID: 5000155124
  • Specific details: exam passed, date, score, and that the badge never arrived.

Prep Credly on your end

  • Make sure the email Credly is using matches your Universal ID email.
  • If not, add that email as a secondary in your Credly account and confirm it at SAP support.credly.com
  • You passed your C_TS4FI_2023 exam on 2 May 2025 with a 75% score and received your result email, but no badge or certificate has arrived, even after raising a support ticket (Case ID: 5000155124) on 4 May. That’s well beyond the usual 24–48-hour delivery window.

What's next to do

  • Verify that Universal ID has two working emails.
  • Check My Learning → Certifications for your exam record.
  • Escalate with SAP, referencing your Case ID under the Digital Badge category.
  • Sync emails in Credly and submit a request if needed.

Let me know if you need further information.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: PATCH Fails for Statistical Condition Types in API_SALES_ORDER_SRV
entry.content:
When attempting to update a Sales Order Pricing Element via the API_SALES_ORDER_SRV service using a PATCH request, the operation fails for certain condition types even though other condition types update successfully.

Example: Updating ConditionRateValue for a specific condition type fails, while other condition types in the same request succeed.

  • Error message: "Field CONDITIONTYPE is not an input field"

The issue occurs specifically when the condition type in the pricing procedure is marked as Statistical.

Has anyone encountered this behavior in the Public Cloud version of SAP S/4HANA? Is there a way to update Statistical condition types via API, or is there an official limitation?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: PATCH Fails for Statistical Condition Types in API_SA...
entry.content:
Yes, this is expected behavior in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition due to how Statistical condition types are handled in pricing procedures.

Root Cause:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, if a condition type is flagged as Statistical in the pricing procedure, it is treated as informational only and does not influence net price calculations. As a result, Statistical condition types are read-only and cannot be updated via PATCH in API_SALES_ORDER_SRV or via the UI.

Resolution / Workarounds:

  1. Confirm in the pricing procedure that the condition type is marked as Statistical.
  2. Use a non-statistical condition type if you need it to be updateable.
  3. For manual adjustments, use the SAP Fiori Manage Sales Orders app.
  4. See SAP Note 2991011 for related API limitations.

I hope this helps!

Sap Support

entry.title: In CBAR Return Delivery, No FI Document is Generated
entry.content:
While using the CBAR standard Return Order type with reference to a billing document, the system creates the return order and delivery in the background.
After posting the goods receipt (PGR), the stock is placed in Blocked Stock.
We then move it to Unrestricted Stock using a stock transfer with movement type 343 E.

However, in the return delivery’s goods issue document, no FI document is generated.
Why is this happening and how can we generate an FI document for a return delivery ? 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: In CBAR Return Delivery, No FI Document is Generated
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, movement type 343 E is designed for internal stock transfers (Blocked → Unrestricted) and is not accounting-relevant.
This is standard system behavior, no FI document is expected for this movement type.

If you require an FI document during the return delivery process, the return must use an accounting-relevant movement type, such as 653, which posts returned goods to unrestricted-use stock and triggers FI postings upon PGR.

The movement type used in a return process is determined by the schedule line category in the return sales order:

  • WN → Movement Type 653 (FI-relevant)

  • DN → Movement Type 651 (typically to blocked stock)

You can change this in configuration activity Assign Schedule Line Categories (SSCUI 105642) to ensure the desired movement type is used.

Reference:
KBA 3563097 – Movement Types in Sales Returns Process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
Customer Returns Processing Help Portal

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Integration Suite and Connection Type G for synchrono...
entry.content:
Hello @CodeMadeInGermany 

A type G HTTP/HTTPS destination in BD97 will not work for synchronous BAPI calls. ALE requires an RFC destination.
If you want to keep BD97, use an RFC Sender adapter in Integration Suite with a matching RFC destination (type T) in SM59. This way, the ABAP system sends a native RFC request that CPI can process.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into the about our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
What is “clean core”?

Let’s dive a bit deeper to understand what exactly this means: An SAP S/4HANA Cloud solution has a clean core when it is up to date, documented, unmodified, consistent, efficient, and has custom extensions decoupled from SAP source code.

The clean core concept has multiple dimensions:

  • Business Processes: reduce complexity, because complex processes slow down upgrade cycles
  • Extensibility: decouple extensions from the standard
  • Data: control the data to the latest standards, with respect to volume, cleanliness, accuracy
  • Integration: keep your IT landscape reliable and flexible, using standard APIs and events
  • Operations: keep your operations effective and efficient

In this blog post, we will focus on the method for maintaining this clean core while adapting SAP solutions to meet specific business needs, which is called “clean core extensibility”. Flexibility will continue to benefit you in the future if extensions are built and utilized in adherence to clean core principles. For this, SAP provides the private cloud extensibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Note: The clean core concept only applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, as the Public Cloud Edition cannot be customized in its source code, only extended. For the public cloud, SAP provides the public cloud extensibility model for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, which also leverages the SAP BTP.

Now, back to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

What Is New: The Evolution Of The 3-Tier Model – Introducing The Clean Core Level Concept

SAP is evolving its extensibility guidelines by introducing the Clean Core Level Concept, a new model designed to simplify qualification criteria and provide a more pragmatic approach to managing custom code in SAP S/4HANA, now including rules for classic ABAP. By evolving the previous 3-tier model, this new maturity model categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D) based on their architectural integrity, upgrade safety, and alignment with clean core principles.

This allows for a more granular assessment of an extension's quality and upgrade stability, rather than a simple binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. The core recommendation remains a "BTP-first" strategy, aiming for the highest possible level, but the new model acknowledges the realities of complex, grown system landscapes and allows customers to  personalize their clean core journeys. The fundamental principles of Clean Core—decoupling extensions from the standard SAP code to ensure upgrade stability—remain essential.

How It Works: The Four Clean Core Levels Explained

According to the Clean Core Level Concept, each extension is evaluated using a standardized methodology that looks at how the extension is built, how well it is decoupled from the core, and how easily it can be upgraded or maintained. Here are the key details of the Clean Core Level Concept:

Overview of Clean Core Levels

The Clean Core Level Concept categorizes extensions into four distinct levels (A, B, C, and D), each representing varying degrees of compliance with Clean Core principles:

  1. Level A : Extend with SAP Build

    • Description: Extensions in this level are fully compliant with Clean Core principles and interact with SAP standard functionality through publicly released interfaces and extension points.
    • Characteristics:
      • Side-by-Side: Developed on SAP BTP, utilizing all options of the SAP Build portfolio including AI-powered pro-code and low-code tools.
      • On-Stack: Built within the SAP S/4HANA system using the ABAP Cloud development model with released APIs.
    • Benefits: Maximum upgrade stability and alignment with SAP's clean core vision.

  2. Level B : Leverage Classic APIs

    • Description: Extensions at this level can access "classic APIs" from SAP, in addition to meeting Level A criteria.
    • Characteristics:
      • These APIs are well-defined, documented, and generally upgrade-stable but do not come with formal stability contracts.
      • Classic technologies and frameworks can be used, which have a long-standing history of reliable use.
    • Benefits: Broader scope for process enhancements compared to Level A while maintaining a degree of upgrade stability.

  3. Level C : Access Internal Objects

    • Description: Extensions classified as Level C can access internal SAP objects that are not officially released or supported.
    • Characteristics:
      • These objects may lack documentation and long-term stability guarantees.
      • A changelog for SAP objects is provided to help customers assess upgrade risks proactively.
    • Benefits: Offers flexibility for legacy scenarios but poses notable risks regarding future upgrade stability.

  4. Level D : Not Recommended Extensions

    • Description: Extensions in this category use objects or techniques that SAP has explicitly marked as "not recommended."
    • Characteristics:
      • Includes modifications to SAP standard code, implicit enhancements, and direct write access to SAP tables.
      • Represents the highest risk and the most significant technical debt.
    • Consequences: These extensions threaten system stability and upgradeability and should be prioritized for immediate remediation.

Importance of the Level Concept

  • Granular Assessment: The level concept allows for a more nuanced evaluation of extensions compared to a binary "clean" or "unclean" decision. This granularity helps organizations understand the specific risks associated with their custom code.
  • Guidance for Development: By categorizing extensions into levels, developers can make informed decisions about which technologies and practices to adopt, aiming for the highest possible level of compliance.
  • Facilitating Modernization: The framework supports organizations in managing their existing codebases effectively, helping them prioritize remediation of the highest-risk extensions (Level D) while promoting the adoption of clean, upgrade-stable practices.

Conclusion

The Clean Core Level Concept is essential for organizations leveraging SAP S/4HANA, offering a clear framework to assess and categorize custom extensions. By distinguishing between Levels A, B, C, and D, it enables businesses to make informed development decisions, prioritize remediation of high-risk extensions, and ensure compliance with Clean Core principles. This structured approach not only helps manage technical debt but also simplifies upgrades and enhances overall system integrity, paving the way for sustained agility and innovation. Embracing this framework is key to maintaining a robust and future-ready ERP landscape.

Leverage SAP Build for creating extensions

The go-to place following SAP-recommended best practices to create extensions optimized for SAP software development is SAP Build. It includes

  • powerful low-code, pro-code (ABAP, Java, JavaScript), and generative AI capabilities
  • enhanced interoperability with SAP S/4HANA

to empower developers and business experts to create extensions for SAP software with greater efficiency. It allows you to accelerate ERP modernization, foster innovation, and automate processes – all within a single comprehensive suite of solutions.

 

Accelerate extension of SAP S/4HANA with AI capabilities enabled by Joule

New levels of Cloud ERP efficiency can be unlocked with the latest AI capabilities enabled by Joule in SAP Build. Joule is SAP’s AI copilot offering conversational interactions in the respective business context. Uniquely trained on SAP data and processes, it helps developers write code and design workflows for SAP S/4HANA across ABAP, Java, JavaScript, and low-code tools. As an integral part of SAP Build, Joule is the copilot for SAP development and makes developers more efficient with their development tasks for SAP S/4HANA.

Joule generates high-quality code and code explanations aligned with SAP’s programming models, thereby reducing development time for both new and experienced developers and accelerating migration to cloud ERP with a clean core.

AI capabilities enabled by Joule can also be used to extend ERP through low-code application development. Joule assists with process automation, expediting the creation of workflows for SAP S/4HANA and guiding workflow approvers with automated recommendations.

How to Get Started?

First and foremost, read our white paper on Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud . The last chapter of the document details the six-step path to a clean core and links to many useful resources to deep dive:

  1. Start with the clean core concept and definition
  2. Apply the concept and create your specific clean core strategy
  3. Analyze existing custom code (brownfield only)
  4. Adopt extension guidelines and methodologies
  5. Establish clean core governance and operations
  6. Build extensions

In addition, depending of the line of business you’re involved in, read our eBook presenting how to Extend SAP S/4HANA with SAP Build with use cases by LoB, including Finance, Supply chain, Sales and service, Operations and IT.

And regarding the use of SAP Build for extending your ERP, I recommend watching the replay of our SAP Build Live online event on Clean Core extensibility with SAP Build held on October 23, where our partner LeverX shared insights from a real customer use case.

In addition, I also recommend watching the replay of some SAP TechEd sessions focused on the Extensibility topic:

  • DT200 | Clean core extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • DT280 | Build clean core extensions with ABAP Cloud for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • AD106 | Clean core extensibility of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition with ABAP Cloud
  • AD100 | Unlock SAP Build and ABAP Cloud interoperability to elevate your extensions
  • AD102 | Unlock SAP S/4HANA Cloud extensibility with SAP Build
  • AD180 | Build extensions with ABAP Cloud and Joule's ABAP developer capabilities
  • AI104 | Revolutionize ABAP development with Joule, our generative AI copilot

Finally, we have two learning journeys for you:

Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud will present you how to evaluate and apply clean core principles to ERP so that they can maximize business process agility, reduce adaptation efforts, and accelerate innovation. It is for beginners, takes 2 hours and is free.

Practicing Clean Core Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud will show you how to implement extensions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud consistent with clean core principles and aligned with your business use cases. It is intermediate level, takes 8 hours and is free until you choose to pass an optional certification.

Now you're ready to begin your fruitful journey to achieve Clean Core!

entry.title: Brazilian Tax Reform
entry.content:
Portuguese version:

           Olá!

           A partir de hoje passaremos a fazer uma série de postagens sobre a Reforma Tributária Brasileira, seu impacto na SAP Business Network (SBN) e assuntos relacionados e com foco nas atividades e potenciais alterações que serão necessárias nas suas integrações, configurações e customizações na SBN.

           Futuras alterações relativas à solução serão comunicadas e acompanhadas diretamente via releases oficiais da SBN pelos nossos times de produto

           Quer conhecer mais e avaliar os impactos nas suas integrações de Commerce Automation com a SBN? Acompanhe com a gente!

 

1. Contexto

           Com base na Emenda Constitucional (EC) 132/2023 e Lei Complementar (LC) 214/2025, o ICMS, ISS, IPI, PIS e COFINS serão substituídos pelo Imposto sobre Valor Agregado (IVA) Dual, em todo o país. O IVA Dual será composto por:

  • IBS (Imposto sobre Bens e Serviços) – de competência estadual e municipal, substituindo o ICMS e o ISS
  • CBS (Contribuição sobre Bens e Serviços) – de competência federal, substituindo PIS, COFINS e IPI

           Será também criado o IS (Imposto Seletivo), que será de competência federal com incidência sobre bens considerados prejudiciais à saúde ou ao meio ambiente, como cigarros e bebidas alcoólicas.

           Além disso, juntamente com as mudanças tributárias, teremos a alteração na composição do CNPJ que passa a ser alfanumérico.

 

           De acordo com as publicações, a mudança será progressiva, ocorrendo gradualmente de 2026 a 2033.

 

2. Mudanças no ERP SAP

           A SAP está trabalhando para atender todos os novos requerimentos com antecedência e periodicamente publicando notas para preparação dos sistemas. As informações e links estão disponíveis em dois canais:

  • Página do Regulatory Change Manager dedicada para o tema
  • Notas em detalhes e conversas com especialistas no Workzone

           Obs: A página é autorizada ao público externo, mas é necessário cadastrar e solicitar acesso.

 

3. Mudanças na SAP Business Network para as Empresas Compradoras

           Se a sua empresa utiliza a SAP Business Network como comprador para transacionar com os seus fornecedores, fique atento às alterações que serão necessárias destacadas abaixo.

           Além disso, algumas definições e ações devem ser tomadas diretamente pelos clientes compradores. Veja abaixo:

 

3.1 Envio e Recebimento de documentos no ERP:

  • Inicialmente, o cliente comprador deve definir como tratará os novos impostos no ERP, se atualizará os IVAs atuais ou se criará novos códigos.  
  • Também é preciso analisar se existem desenvolvimentos relativos aos campos relevantes (CNPJ e impostos) para o enriquecimento dos arquivos (idocs, proxys, etc) enviados e recebidos da SAP Business Network. Em caso positivo, o cliente deve revisar as customizações feitas para garantir que não serão afetadas pela mudança no formato do CNPJ e pelos novos impostos.

 

3.2 Mapeamentos na integração:

  • O cliente deve revisar os mapeamentos customizados, caso tenha, do envio e do recebimento de documentos. O objetivo também é garantir que não ocorram impactos.

           Exemplo de mapeamento customizado para CNPJ: neste caso, o cliente envia o CNPJ em apenas um campo no idoc. No mapeamento, o número é enviado para diversos campos dentro do cmxl, como o ShipTo. Deve ser realizada análise para garantir de que o envio de CNPJ alfanumérico não afetará a personalização realizada.

           Exemplo de mapeamento customizado para impostos: o campo standard para envio dos impostos é o E1EDP01/E1EDP04. Neste caso, o cliente envia os impostos no segmento E1EDP05 e possui mapeamento personalizado para correta migração das informações. Veja o comparativo:

            Standard – Mantendo o envio no campo E1EDP01/E1EDP04, não há necessidade de customização no CIG:

           Impostos Atuais:

                     E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>IPI</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>IPI não dedutível</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>
                     <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>ICMS</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>ICMS não-dedutível</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>

           Previsão de composição do idoc com os impostos novos:

                     <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>CBS</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>CBS</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>
                     <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                        <MWSKZ>IBS</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>IBS</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>

           Customizado – Envio dos impostos no campo E1EDP01/E1EDP05, há necessidade de customização no CIG.

           Impostos Atuais:

                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>IPI</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>
                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>ICMS</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>

           Previsão de composição do idoc com os impostos novos:

                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>CBS</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           </E1EDP05>
                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>IBS</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>

 

3.3 Customizações e configurações na SBN:

  • Conferir na documentação do projeto se foram realizadas customizações nas telas da SAP Business Network em lógicas ou campos relevantes aos CNPJs e impostos. Em caso positivo, a necessidade deve ser sinalizada para a gestão da sua conta, pois as customizações de telas são realizadas apenas pela equipe SAP.
  • Caso possua lista de impostos personalizada, revisar a lista de impostos cadastrados na regra de transação “Require suppliers to choose from your list of valid tax values ” dentro da opção “Default Transaction Rules ”.

Account Settings / Manage Profile / Default Transaction Rules / Require suppliers to choose from your list of valid tax values / Configure

 

  • O cliente fornecedor que possui integração da SAP Business Network com o ERP deve revisar os seus mapeamentos e transformação de dados, garantindo que estão preparados para receber os novos formatos de CNPJ e  novos impostos (Em breve novas informações sobre essa atividade serão divulgadas).

 

4. Mudanças na SAP Business Network para as Empresas Fornecedoras

           Se a sua empresa utiliza a SAP Business Network como fornecedor para transacionar com os seus compradores e tem a plataforma integrada com o seu ERP, fique atento às necessidades de ajustes no envio e recebimento de dados. Em breve divulgaremos novidades detalhando quais são os potenciais ajustes que sua equipe TI ou parceiro SAP deve realizar.

 

Dúvidas?

           Se tiver algum questionamento procure a gestão da sua conta para solicitar ajuda pontual e revisão da sua solução.

 

English version:

           Hello!

           Starting today, we will begin a series of posts about the Brazilian Tax Reform, its impact on the SAP Business Network (SBN), and related topics, focusing on the activities and potential changes that will be necessary in your integrations, configurations, and customizations in the SBN.

           Future changes related to the solution will be communicated and monitored directly via official SBN releases by our product team.

 

1. Context

           Based on the Constitutional Amendment (EC) 132/2023 and Complementary Law (LC) 214/2025, the ICMS, ISS, IPI, PIS, and COFINS will be replaced by Dual Value Added Tax (VAT). The Dual VAT will consist of:

  • IBS (Tax on Goods and Services) – state and municipal competence, replacing ICMS and ISS
  • CBS (Contribution on Goods and Services) – federal competence, replacing PIS, COFINS and IPI

           The Selective Tax (IS) will also be created, which will be of federal competence and will apply to goods considered harmful to health or the environment, such as cigarettes and alcoholic beverages.

           Additionally, along with the tax changes, there will be a change in the composition of the CNPJ, which will become alphanumeric.

           According to the government publications, the change will be progressive, occurring gradually from 2026 to 2033.

 

2. Changes in SAP ERP

           SAP is working to meet all new requirements in advance and periodically publishing notes for system preparation. Information and links are available through two channels:

  • Regulatory Change Manager page dedicated to the topic 
  • Notes in detail and conversations with experts in the Workzone

Note: The page is authorized to the external public, but it is necessary to register and request access.

 

3. Changes in SAP Business Network for Buyer Companies

           If your company uses SAP Business Network as a buyer to transact with your suppliers, pay attention to the necessary changes highlighted below. Some definitions and actions must be taken directly by the buyer customers. See below:

 

3.1 Sending and Receiving Documents in ERP:

  • Initially, the buyer customer must define how it will handle the new taxes in the ERP, whether to update the current VATs, or to create new codes. 
  • It is also necessary to analyze if there are any developments related to relevant fields (CNPJ and taxes) for the enrichment of files (idocs, proxys, etc.) sent and received from SAP Business Network. If so, the customer must review the customizations made to ensure they will not be affected by the change in CNPJ format and the new taxes.

 

3.2 Customized Mappings:

  • The customer must review the custom mappings, if any, from sending and receiving documents. The goal is also to ensure that no impacts occur.

           Example of custom mapping for CNPJ: in this case, the customer sends the CNPJ in only one field in the idoc. In the mapping, the number is sent to various fields within the cmxl, such as ShipTo. An analysis must be realized to ensure that alphanumeric CNPJ will not affect the customization performed.

           Example of customized mapping for taxes: the standard segment for sending taxes is E1EDP01/E1EDP04. In this case, the customer sends the taxes in segment E1EDP05 and has a custom mapping to migrates the information. See the comparison:

            Standard – Sending taxes in the segment E1EDP01/E1EDP04, there is no need for customization in CIG:

           Current Taxes:

                     E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>IPI</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>IPI Non-Deductible</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>
                     <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>ICMS</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>ICMS Non-Deductible</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>

           Estimated idoc with new taxes:

                     <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>CBS</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>CBS</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>
                     <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">
                           <MWSKZ>IBS</MWSKZ>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                           <MWSBT>0.00</MWSBT>
                           <TXJCD>MG</TXJCD>
                           <KTEXT>IBS</KTEXT>
                     </E1EDP04>

           Customized – Sending taxes in the segment E1EDP01/E1EDP05, customization in CIG is needed.

           Current Taxes:

                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>IPI</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>
                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>ICMS</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>

 

           Estimated idoc with new taxes:

                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>CBS</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>
                     <E1EDP05 SEGMENT="1">
                           <KOTXT>IBS</KOTXT>
                           <KRATE>0.00</KRATE>
                           <KOBTR>0.00</KOBTR>
                           <MSATZ>0.00</MSATZ>
                     </E1EDP05>

 

3.3 SBN Customization and Configuration:

  • Check in the project documentation if customizations were made on the SAP Business Network templates or in relevant fields for CNPJs and taxes. If so, contact your SAP account manager, as screen customizations are only customized by the SAP team.
  • If you have a customized tax list, review the list of taxes registered in the transaction rule “Require suppliers to choose from your list of valid tax values ” within the “Default Transaction Rules ” option.

Account Settings / Manage Profile / Default Transaction Rules / Require suppliers to choose from your list of valid tax values / Configure

 

  • The supplier customer who has SAP Business Network integration with the ERP must review their mappings and data transformation, ensuring that they are prepared to receive the new tax ID formats and new taxes (more information about this activity will be disclosed soon).

 

4. Changes in SAP Business Network for Supplier Companies

           If your company uses SAP Business Network as a supplier to transact with your buyers and has the platform integrated with your ERP, pay attention to the need for adjustments in data sending and receiving. We will soon release news detailing what potential adjustments your IT team or SAP partner should make.

 

Questions?

                If you have any questions, contact your SAP account manager to request specific help and review your solution.

entry.title: "More (F5)" Button disappeared in SAP Screen Personas after flavors edited

Original Screen:

Edited screen with flavor: (Below in edit mode to show nothing is hidden)

Please suggest.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud - Data Actions - Advance Formula Step
entry.content:
Hello Team,

I have a data action using an Advanced Formula Step where the calculation logic is duplicated by employee category, differing only by the attribute used to fetch PERCENTAGE. The current version is forSALARIEDemployees.

Now, for HOURLYemployees, the calculated value should post to a different account (GL_HOURLY), but the logic remains identical except for the GL account.

Question:
Instead of duplicating the entire formula with GL_Account = "GL_HOURLY" for hourly employees (resulting in 4 separate DATA statements - 2 each for each employee category), is there a cleaner or more efficient approach? For example, can the GL account be dynamically assigned based on employee category within a single formula to avoid redundancy?

 This data action is being called in a multi action after loading actuals.

Thanks, 

PS

<li-code lang="abap">DATA([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_SALARIED") =
		(RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_1", [d/TIME] = NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-MERIT", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_1", [d/TIME] = NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_2", [d/TIME] = NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-MERIT", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_2", [d/TIME] = NEXT( - 1, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_1", [d/TIME] = NEXT( - 2, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-MERIT", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_1", [d/TIME] = NEXT( - 2, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_2", [d/TIME] = NEXT( - 2, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-MERIT", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_2", [d/TIME] = NEXT( - 2, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_1", [d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-MERIT", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_1", [d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_2", [d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH"))
		 + RESULTLOOKUP([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-MERIT", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_2", [d/TIME] = NEXT(0, "MONTH")))
		* (RESULTLOOKUP([d/MEASURE_TYPE] = [d/HRPOSITION].[p/CORP_GRADE], [d/DATASRC] = "INPUT", [d/Measures] = "PERCENTAGE", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "#", [d/CURRENCY] = "#", [d/COSTCENTER] = "#", [d/HRPOSITION] = "#", [d/EMPLOYEE] = "#", [d/START_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/END_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/SHIFT] = "#", [d/TERM_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/GRADE] = "#", [d/EMPCATE] = "#", [d/EMPSTAT] = "#", [d/LABOR_TYPE] = "#"))

entry.title: Re: "More (F5)" Button disappeared in SAP Screen Personas...
entry.content:
Hmm... that's strange.

There must be some change to that control which makes it invisible. If you cannot locate it in the editor, then the goal would be to get rid of any change related to the button, so it potentially becomes visible again.

First, determine the button's control ID by creating a new flavor from scratch and selecting it in the layout or script editor.

Create a copy of your problematic flavor, so we don't mess anything up by experimenting. Then, try compressing the change / undo history of this new flavor and see if this makes a difference. Even if this doesn't fix anything, at least it decreases the changes we need to deal with.

Then, let's do some hacking. Download the flavor from the Admin app and take a look at the included 'changes*' XML files.  Try to locate changes to the button's control ID you identified earlier. If you do find any, delete them from all 'changes*' XML files, update the flavor's ZIP with your changes and then reupload it to check if this made the button accessible again.

If all else fails, I suppose it would be possible to create a button and assign the function of pressing F5 to it as a replacement of the standard one.

entry.title: Re: To integrate s4hana public cloud with sap PaPM system
entry.content:
Hello @897654208074 

SAP offers a dedicated integration guide for connecting SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud with SAP Profitability and Performance Management (PaPM). This guide details setup procedures, communication configurations, and data replication processes.

You can follow the official documentation here:

  • SAP Help – Integrating SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP PaPM:

API Guide for SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud

SAP also has a short enablement video on the SAP Learning site:

Integration of SAP S/4HANA Cloud with SAP PaPM (Learning Video)

Fellow below steps

  • Establish a communication system and setup in S/4HANA Cloud for PaPM APIs.
  • Enable the relevant API API_CostCenterData, API_GLAccountBalance
  • Configure the connection in PaPM using the S/4HANA Cloud endpoint and credentials.
  • Test and schedule the data replication or extraction accordingly.

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Restricted recording profile in Enable Now not working
entry.content:
Hi,

Enable Now is having issues recognizing the application that you are recording.  The issue is likely to be one of two things:

1. To record browser-based applications, Enable Now requires that the browser containing the application, in this case your Fiori application, must have a browser extension installed that allows Enable Now to access the browser application details during recording.  Assuming that you are recording using either Producer or Instant Producer, all authors must install either the Edge or Chrome browser extension
2. Producer and Instant Producer must be able to run with Administrator privileges.  This SAP Note provides details about allowing Producer and Instant Producer to run with Admin privileges

 

Regards
Shane

entry.title: Re: How to anonymize User data in FRUN Real User monitoring?
entry.content:
Dear customer,

You can achieve this by restricting the roles as describing in

https://help.sap.com/docs/FRUN/6ba510f3be2945e19e497bfb1065b022/9695b97f7d5349c0b94c3e6e6d6adadf.html#integration-and-user-monitoring.

Either the user gets SAP_FRN_APP_RUM_WOD then he cannot see user names OR SAP_FRN_APP_RUM_ALL then he can display the user names.

 

Best regards,

Ava Wang

entry.title: SAP Databricks: Building an Intelligent Enterprise with AI Unleashed – Part 4
entry.content:
Part 1 – SQL analytics with SAP Data Products
Part 2 – Build and deploy Mosaic AI and Agent Tools
Part 3 – Connect SAP Data Products with non-SAP data from AWS S3
Part 4 – End-to-end integration: SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud
Part 5 – Create inferences and endpoints for application integration with SAP Build

SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud 

In the earlier parts of this series, we explored SAP Databricks' advanced capabilities—from SQL and AI/ML analytics to integrating SAP Data Products with external sources such as AWS S3.

Now, we turn our focus to a holistic view of the SAP Business Data Cloud ecosystem—showcasing how seamless, governed, end-to-end data sharing can be achieved. In this post, we’ll demonstrate how SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) work together to form a Business Data Fabric.

This blog post is written in collaboration with @shairin_abdulaziz, as we explore frontiers in data interoperability within SAP Business Data Cloud and examine how enterprises can unlock greater value.


Services and Components within SAP Business Data Cloud

  • SAP BDC Cockpit: Centralized management interface for SAP BDC.
  • SAP Datasphere: Centralized data management platform supporting self-service, semantic onboarding, and integration with data marketplaces.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): Provides advanced analytics and visualization capabilities.
  • Data Products: Standardized datasets for AI/ML and cross-domain analytics. Exposed for consumption outside the producing application via APIs, described by high-quality metadata, and semantically aligned for access through the Data Product Directory.
  • Data Packages: Logical grouping of data products, used as foundations for modelling in SAP Datasphere or for AI/ML scenarios in SAP Databricks.
  • Intelligent Applications: Pre-built applications for actionable intelligence. Low-code apps are composed of data products, data models, and SAC content. SAC content demonstrates the underlying data products to fulfil specific analytics use cases. Customers can extend the analytical layer to meet specific requirements.

End-to-end Integration: SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud

  1. Activate an Intelligent Application or a Data Package in the SAP Business Data Cloud Cockpit. Data replication occurs for the respective Data Products into the BDC Object Store
  2. Data Products are available via the BDC Catalog
  3. Select and share a Data Product with SAP Databricks (target system). The Data Product will be accessible as a Delta Table via SAP Databricks Unity Catalog
  4. Build custom data products in SAP Databricks with AI/ML, and delta share the derived data product back to SAP BDC Cockpit
  5. Share derived data product into SAP Datasphere
  6. Conduct data modelling and share results with SAP Analytics Cloud for visualizations

Step-by-Step Playbook

Required Roles and Prerequisites

  • Metastore Admin in SAP Databricks (or Metastore Admin can grant user USE recipient rights for delta sharing)
  • Datasphere Catalog Admin
  1. Metastore Admin to CREATE recipient “sap-business-data-cloud"
  2. Metastore Admin to grant USE recipient rights for the user before the user can delta share back to the BDC catalog. Without USE recipient right, you’ll not be able to see “sap-business-data-cloud” as a recipient
  3. Delta Sharing requires specific formats, e.g., complex views are not allowed for delta sharing
  4. When creating a Delta table that will be exposed as Data Products via Delta Sharing, you must
    disable deletion vectors and enable change data feed. 
  5. You’ll have to set your primary key in the CSN code or within the table

Note: SAP Databricks is the Delta Sharing client and receives SAP Data Products only through delta sharing, which is federated data and read-only (no data is persisted). We will release a "Partner Connect" Delta Share connector that will allow companies to connect their existing Databricks to SAP Business Data Cloud with zero-copy data integration.

Reference Architecture


1. Log in to SAP Databricks, View Delta Shares Received, Create a Notebook, and Query Data Products

2. Create a New Share to BDC Recipient (sap-business-data-cloud)

Note: If you do not see the recipient – sap-business-data-cloud, the metastore administrator needs to grant USE recipient access to your user account.

Metastore administrator can run this code to grant user access:

GRANT USE RECIPIENT ON METASTORE TO `name@sap.com`;

3. Create Share with ORD, Create CSN, Publish Data Products from the Python Notebook environment

Exact code under sap-bdc-connect-sdk: https://pypi.org/project/sap-bdc-connect-sdk/#create-or-update-share-csn 



4. Log in to SAP BDC Catalog and view your published Data Product

5. Install your Data Product to SAP Datasphere

6. Create SAP Datasphere Analytical Model for Consumption in SAP Analytics Cloud

Once the Data Product is shared and installed, you can utilize the Data Product as a modeling artifact in SAP Datasphere to expose the data to SAP Analytics Cloud for reporting and dashboarding purposes.

  • In Datasphere, you'll find your Data Product in the space where it is installed. SAP Datasphere includes standard and custom Data Products.
  • The Data Product can now be used to create views (Fact/Dimension), which will be used to generate the Analytic Model (Cube) in the Data Builder
  • Expose the required fields from both the Fact and Dimension for consumption
  • Save and deploy to ensure the Analytic Model is in a ready state for consumption
  • Now, this can be used by SAP Analytics Cloud for Business Intelligence

With seamless integration between SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud, enterprises can now enable governed, end-to-end data sharing and unlock unified insights across their data landscape. By turning Data Products into analytical models, and visualizing them through SAC, organizations can drive smarter, real-time decision-making—powered by both SAP and non-SAP data sources.

In the next part of our series, we’ll explore how to create inferences and deploy endpoints for application integration using SAP Build—bringing AI-driven insights directly into low-code business applications. Stay tuned!

Is there a solution on release 500?

entry.title: Re: Need license key for SAP BO 4.2 to 4.3 upgrade
entry.content:
Regarding to your issue, kindly refer to KBA 2251998 - How to generate license keys for SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform (all versions) - SAP for Me

  1. In SAP for Me, open License Keys
  2. Select/Search for the installation number :20*****
  3. Click + Add New System
  4. Enter system data as follows:
    • Product: SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence platform
    • Version: SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence platform 4.3
    • System ID: Enter any 3 alphanumeric characters starting with a letter A-Z (e.g. "B43")    Tip: See KBA 2952755 for more information.
    • System name: Optional free text
    • System type: Select from drop-down (e.g. Productive, Test, Development, Backup)
    • Operating System: Select from drop-down
  5. Click Continue
  6. Click + Add License Key
    • Material: Select from drop-down list  Tip: See KBA 2947504 for more information.
    • Version: XI 4.3
    • Number of Licenses:  Enter the quantity needed  Tip: The amount available is displayed in the material choosed above. See KBA 2952762
  7. Click Add
  8. Steps 1-7 should be repeated if multiple license keys for the same product/version are desired to be generated.
  9. Select the license material(s)
  10. Click Generate

Then download the new key to install in your system which is 4.3 version.
